questions.text: What is the most common site of ectopic testis?
questions.solution:
The most common site of ectopic testes is the superficial inguinal pouch.

Testes develop from the genital ridge in the retroperitoneum at 3 months of intrauterine life. They descend into the scrotum by 9 months of age due to differential abdominal growth, pull of the gubernaculum, and the effect of testosterone. 

Cryptorchidism refers to the absence of one or both testes in the scrotal sac. The descent of the testis can be arrested in its usual path of descent (true undescended testis) or can migrate from the usual path of descent (ectopic testis).

The image below shows the possible sites of the testes in cryptorchidism:

A retractile testis can also lie in the inguinal canal and needs to be differentiated between an ectopic testes. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally moves into the inguinal canal. 

An ectopic testis is treated with orchidopexy, while a retractile testis requires no intervention as it resolves spontaneously.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the ideal age for orchidopexy in this child?
questions.solution:
Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.

Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications:

  • Infertility
  • Malignancy (Risk may still exist post surgery)
  • Hernia
  • Testicular torsion
  • Infection

The management for undescended testes that are not palpable is:

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was brought to the OPD as the mother noticed that the scrotum contained only one testicle. On examination, the testis is not palpable in the inguinal region or abdomen. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals abdominal testes and orchiopexy is done. Which of the following tumors is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The tumor most likely to develop in this patient is seminoma.

The tumor that develops most commonly in undesceded testes is germ cell tumor in situ or intratubular germ cell tumor. It commonly progresses into seminomas.

In patients with a nonpalpable testicle, diagnostic laparoscopy is performed. If testis is still not visualised, the spermatic cord or testicular artery is traced at the deep inguinal ring to locate it.

If a blind ending spermatic cord is found instead, vanishing testis syndrome (or testicular regression syndrome) is suspected. It is the partial or total absence of testicular tissue often due to an ischemic event in foetal life.

The testis once found can be delivered into the scrotum, and an orchidopexy is performed.

questions.text: A newborn was diagnosed with undescended testes. Due to the intra-abdominal location of the testes, a two-stage Stephen-Fowler’s orchiopexy was planned. Which of the following is performed during the first stage of this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the first stage of a two-stage Stephens-Fowler approach, the testicular vessels are clipped. 

Clipping of the testicular artery promotes neo vasculogenesis along the vas deferens. It does not result in ischemia of the testis due to the presence of collaterals from the cremasteric artery and the artery to the ductus deferens (deferential artery).

Several months later, after collaterals are established, the second stage is performed during which the testis and its new blood supply is mobilized into the scrotum.

Stephen-Fowler’s approach is done when an intra abdominal testes is located too far to reach the scrotum. Alternatively, Silbar’s orchiopexy may be done. In this procedure, microvascular anastomosis of the testicular vessels with internal illiac vessels is done after the testis is mobilised to the scrotum.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of testicular torsion?

choices.text: Presence of remnant of mullerian duct
Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis

questions.solution:
High investment of the tunica vaginalis is the most common cause of torsion of testis. It causes the testes to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause of testicular torsion in adolescents.

Bell clapper testes are typically bilateral. The image below shows the bell-clapper deformity of the testes:

Other abnormalities that cause torsion of the testes:

  • Inversion of the testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.

  • Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis by a pedicle allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

An appendix testis is a small vestigial appendage located on the upper pole of the testis. Twisting of the appendage causes testicular appendix torsion. In it, a classic blue dot sign is seen on the upper pole of the testis. It is seen as a hard tender nodule with a blue discoloration on the superior aspect of the testis. This is a remnant of the Mullerian duct, that regresses on development.

The image below shows the blue dot sign on the testis:

Note: This is a controversial question.

The latest edition of Bailey and Love 27th edition, page no 1500, lists high investment of the tunica vaginalis as the most common cause of torsion of testes. On the other hand, the 26th edition, page no 1379, lists inversion of testes as the most common cause. There is no consensus among other books. Therefore, according to the most updated version of Bailey and Love, the most common cause of torsion testes is high investment of the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable.  Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Signs seen on torsion of the testis are:

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis

Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended.

Manual detorsion of the testes is usually difficult because of acute pain during manipulation. Nonoperative manual detorsion is not a substitute for surgical exploration.

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side. After the de-torsion, the adequacy of the blood flow has to be assessed by Doppler.

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis. The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination, the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical. 

Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis.

At the time of surgical exploration, contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the dartos fascia in order to prevent possible torsion occurring in this testes.

More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile and a Prehn’s sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with painless swelling of the scrotum. Examination revealed a firm, enlarged epididymis along with beading of the vas deferens. Testes were normal. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Send urine or semen for PCR

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testis on palpation indicate secondary tubercular epididymo-orchitis. The next best step is confirmation with polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 

Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genital tuberculosis.

A scrotal USG will reveal an enlarged epididymis but does not have diagnostic value. Chest, kidney, and upper urinary tract imaging may reveal a primary focus.

Tuberculous epididymo-orchitis is usually secondary and resolves once the primary focus is treated. Hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidence of disease elsewhere.

If resolution does not occur within two months, epididymectomy or orchidectomy is advisable.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discolored scrotum as shown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the following statements is true about his condition?

choices.text: Managed by antibiotics and scrotal support
Staphylococcus is the most common causative organism
The condition is usually self limiting

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene in which the testis is classically spared.

It lies naked following debridement of the gangrenous skin and is tucked subcutaneously into the thigh. It is also called "shameful exposure of the testis." 

Fournier’s gangrene is a surgical emergency. It is a life-threatening disease, with a mortality of over 40% even with treatment. It is due to a mixed infection of both aerobic and anaerobic bacterial flora.

Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. 

It is managed by debridement, wide surgical excision, IV fluids, and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents with a scrotal swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is brilliantly transilluminant and the testes cannot be palpated separately. Which additional clinical finding is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The scrotal swelling is most likely a hydrocele. Due to the movement of fluid, a fluctuation test is positive.

Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. It is brilliantly transilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. As it arises in the scrotum, it is possible to get above the swelling. It is irreducible and cough impulse is absent.

A USG will show anechoic reflection due to fluid collection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of a secondary hydrocele ?
questions.solution:
A secondary hydrocele is most commonly caused by an acute or chronic epididymo-orchitis. Other causes of secondary hydrocele include torsion of the testis and testicular tumors.

Primary vaginal hydrocele Secondary vaginal hydrocele
Due to defective absorption of fluid Due to increased secretion of fluid
Tense swelling Lax swelling
Testis not palpable separately Testis palpable separately
Transillumination positive (clear fluid present) Transillumination negative (turbid fluid present)

questions.text: A patient with hydrocele is scheduled for Lord’s plication. Which of the following is false regarding the procedure?

choices.text: The procedure can be performed under local anesthesia
Increased risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay's
Preferred for small to medium sized swellings
Tunica vaginalis is bunched to obliterate the hydrocoele sac

questions.solution:
Lord's plication has a lower risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay's procedure. 

Hydrocele may be managed surgically by various techniques. Lord's plication and Jaboulay's eversion of the sac are most commonly performed. 

Jaboulay's eversion of the sac is preferred for large hydroceles. In this method, the tunica vaginalis sac is everted around the testis. Although it has a shorter operative time, the risk of hematoma formation is more. 

Congenital hydroceles are managed by a herniotomy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.

The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination:


It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable.

Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. 

Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance.

Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a varicocele. As this patient is young and infertile, varicocelectomy is indicated and a Palomo procedure may be performed. 

Varicocele may present with a dull aching scrotal pain and enlargement. Additionally, patients may have infertility. A bag of worms, which gets prominent on Valsalva’s maneuver is palpated due to the engorged pampiniform plexus.

Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment.

Grades of varicocele
Grade 1 Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 2 Varicocele palpable without Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 3 Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

Left-sided varicocele is more common. Isolated right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion of renal cell carcinoma.

(Note: Varicoceles occurs on left side more commonly as the left spermatic vein opens at sharp angle to the left renal vein, whereas, on the right side, the right spermatic vein opens into a larger Inferior vena cava and an isolated Right-sided varicocele may indicate a tumour that compresses the venous return in the inferior vena cava)

Treatment of young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:

  • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method )
  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) 
  • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route

In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing testicular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Benzopyrene exposure is not associated with an increased risk of developing testicular cancer but with an increased risk of developing scrotal carcinoma.

Shale oil exposure (a petroleum byproduct) is also associated with an increased incidence of scrotal carcinoma. 

Undescended testes, history of contralateral testicular tumor, and Klinefelter's syndrome are known to increase one’s risk to develop testicular cancer. 

Note: Patients with Klinefelter’s syndrome also have an increased risk of developing extragonadal germ cell tumors.

questions.text:
Which among the following are germ-cell tumors?
  1. Leydig cell tumor 
  2. Embryonal cell carcinoma
  3. Choriocarcinoma
  4. Sertoli cell tumor
  5. Teratoma
  6. Yolk-sac tumor
questions.solution:
Germ-cell tumors (90–95%) include seminoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, yolk-sac tumor, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma. 

Leydig and Sertoli cell tumors are non-germ-cell tumors.

Related Pearl: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.

The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.

Other options:

Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they are typically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. In approximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli. 

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.  Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. More undifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation in cell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are frequently seen.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originating in all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) or immature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding testicular tumors?

choices.text: They may present as an abdominal lump.
Testicular biopsy is done to diagnose testicular carcinoma.
Seminomas metastasize predominantly via the lymphatic system.
Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.

questions.solution:
There is no role of testicular biopsy in the diagnosis of testicular tumors. This is due to the risk of seeding tumor cells onto the scrotal wall.

In testicular tumors, the most common site of lymphatic spread is retroperitoneal lymph nodes which may present as an abdominal lump. 

Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.  Few seminomas may have elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) or beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG). Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a marker of tumor bulk.

Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors that metastasize via lymphatics. Non-germ-cell tumors arise from Sertoli or Leydig cells and follow a more benign course. Approximately only 10% are malignant.

questions.text: A patient with a left-sided testicular tumor is being evaluated for metastasis. Which group of lymph nodes is most likely to get involved first?
questions.solution:
The first sites of metastasis in left-sided testicular tumors are the para-aortic lymph nodes.

Testicular tumors metastasize first to the retroperitoneal nodes. Right-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the interaortocaval nodes. Left-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the left para-aortic nodes.

Deep inguinal lymph nodes receive drainage from the perineum and lower extremity. Inguinal lymph nodes may be involved if the testicular tumor spreads to the skin of the scrotum.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with a hard painless testicular lump with a dragging sensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is least likely to be included, in further management of this case?

AFP- Alpha Fetoprotein

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the testis. Orchidectomy via a scrotal approach is not done due to fear of seeding the tumor in the scrotal skin. Instead, an inguinal approach is used.

Raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the testis.

Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor. Tumor markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer. CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is done to detect metastasis.

In testicular tumors, the BEP regimen is followed with bleomycin, etoposide, cisplatin.

  • Poor follow up

questions.text: A patient with Stage I seminoma underwent an orchidectomy 3 months ago. On a follow-up visit, elevated LDH levels were seen. What is the most appropriate line of management?

choices.text: Regular scanning using CT and tumor marker measurement

questions.solution:
Platinum-based therapy is the primary treatment of stage I seminomas following orchidectomy for patients with poor prognostic factors such as elevated tumor markers. It consists of a cycle of single-agent carboplatin.

Management of testicular tumors
